reviewText: Growing up, watching CHiPs, I didn't realize how good a show it was until I saw the reruns years later on TV.  Larry Wilcox (John Baker) and Erik Estrada (Ponch) worked together so well, as did many of the other actors on the show.  There had to be more wrecks and stunts on this show than any other TV show of its time.After 30 years since it first aired, Season 1 is finally on DVD, and I have been watching the 22 episodes, enjoying them more than ever.  I also enjoy Erik Estrada's notes on certain episodes.  I just wish that they had a "Makings of CHiPs" bonus feature.  Maybe they will have that on a future season release, which I am looking forward to.Also, to note, I met both Larry and Erik in Canton, Ohio, when they were, separately, guests at a local car show at the Canton Civic Center, back in the late 70's and early 80's.  I wish I had photos, but I wasn't into photography back then."CHiPs" is definitely one of my all time favorite TV shows!

reviewText: Are you a fan of 70's TV? If so,this DVD set is a must have,with stars such as Erik Estrada,Robert Pine & Larry Wilcox,Chips is a must have DVD set.All 22 episodes of the entire First Season from this Hit of the 70's are herein.There are even facts from Erik Estrada himself on select episodes....i was somewhat disappointed that there are not more features...there are no interviews of how chips came about,nothing from the filming,nothing from anyone but Erik Estrada.Do not get me wrong.This set has all the comedy and drama that i used to watch as a child with the Police Officers i grew up with and loved to watch.It is hard to believe however that this first season set did not have any behind the scene features.Only had facts from Estrada....but the bottom line is this set is a must have for any 70's TV fan...the money is certainly worth it to relive the days of yesteryear with our favorite CHP officers.I can only hope that Season 2 has more features to share with the fans of this wonderful show from the all the stars we grew up with.

reviewText: As a teenager during the show's original run, I thought that "CHiPs" was not very intelligent, poorly written, and poorly performed.  By the early 80's the show was so consistently bad, that for me it really became "appointment television".  Remembering all of the laughs this show brought me during those years, I could not resist purchasing "CHiPs", the first season.  After viewing a handful of episodes, I realized that my adolescent assessment of this series was less than accurate--"CHiPs" is even worse than I remembered.  To anyone who considers him/herself a student of television, "CHiPs" the first season is a "must-have" for your collection.

reviewText: I loved this show.  Always looked forward to watching it back then.  I only remember a handful of episodes I got to watch, surely less than half of all that aired in its 6-year run.  I'd watch it whenever I could, but admittedly I'd moved on to something else by the time it went off in 1983.  The episodes in Season 1, I don't remember seeing any at all (ditto for Season 6 sans Larry Wilcox), but I finally got to see all except the last 3 and enjoyed them all.  Will finish this season soon and I believe I'll like the rest too as well.  One episode I particularly remember featured, if I remember right, a group of kids running around haphazardly without adult supervision in a big stationwagon, even on the freeway at one point, and this one had Robbie Rist in it (Cousin Oliver on the last season of the Brady Bunch).  However, I just learned that he must've appeared in CHiPs before because he was in one episode in this season, about something else.  He seemed as short as he was on TBB, but seemed taller in the aforementioned episode.I forgot how funny the halting closing credits were, but hated this part cuz it meant it's over and I'd have to wait another week for the next episode, even if it's a rerun I'd already seen.  Yeah, I still hate them even on DVD, cuz they're so much fun to watch!!!  Ahh well, at least I can simply move on to the next episode til I get them all on the DVD I got in the player!  Oh, the funniest closings?  That'd be the one in episode 4 titled Moving Violation.  Seeing poor Ponch's frightened face really cracked me up.  Priceless!!!Hopefully the rest of the series will come out, too.  Will get them all if I can!
summary: So much fun to watch.  Sometimes too funny!

reviewText: This show came out my first year of college. We'll get to that in just a sec. I just love big Kawis. The KZ 1000 police original B and C series bikes sounded so good. The Z type engine always got my attention with that cool sound from the straight cut spur gear on the crank that drives the transmission. Ok, tmi ha ha. I ran out and bought one as soon as used police bikes were available. Mine had only 30,000 on it and I rode that bike all over the LA area, even to the LA central CHP office where the show was filmed. Just visiting, no fix it cite. After all, I grew up in So. Cal. I've owned several KZ 1100s. "A" series, LTDs, etc. My neighbour owns an original '73 and '74 900 Z1R. The newer Bimmer R1150 RT0P is a great bike also, it's the police bike of the next generation after Kawasaki stopped building the KZ1000 P series. A faithful soldier that will be fondly remembered.Oh yeah, on to the show. The characters work well, plots are fun and cinematography is tremendous! Cheers to John and Ponch. (Larry Wilcox, Erik Estrada) Great chemistry between the leads and Robert Pine, who played Sgt. Joe Getrare. The character reminds me of guys I've worked for in the past. Good sense of humor, down to business, and likable. My only problem with the series is that it got sillier as the seasons progressed and the disco music and beat get a little old after a while. It progressively got schmaltzy and the writing could have used some freshing up but it's still fun, great escapist TV. The pilot is the one of my favourite shows of the series. You really get to know and like the characters right off. Finally, it's on DVD, albeit first season. Looking forward to the subsequent seasons and a copy of the movie "CHiPS '99" which I have on VHS. That's also fun. Good writing, action, and lots of Kawasakis. If you love big bikes, lots of guy stuff, and pretty ladies with nice smiles, don't miss this one. Cudos to Rick Rosner. Nice shooting. This show still has wheels. Meanwhile, if you're a Chippie riding a Bimmer and a guy on a Blue BMW K 1200 GT waves, that's me. Happy riding and thanks for keeping us safe. Enjoy the show, it's worth every minute.
summary: Fun and lots of big Kawis.

reviewText: Was a HUGE fan of the show growing up and have waited a long time to have this accessible on DVD. It was on TNT a few years back at like 4am which I caughts only after a late night of drinking on days I worked afternoons and evenings. As annoying as I found Ponch (even as a 10 year old when the show was on tv), the chase scenes, the female and California scenery make the show timeless. Favorite episode was "Name your Price" with stolen Rolls Royces and Ponch "preparing" for a show "Name your Price" with an ironic ending with the item he has to "Name the price on." Also, season 1 was the only season with the "slowed down" theme music before season 2's "updated" theme which stuck till the end. I personally found the 79'-80' season the best (season 3) with episodes like the Bingo BMX and the hypocritical reverends/preachers that counterfit money (very appropriate seeing as most pastors "are tax free and steal").Anyhow, while I found the first season not the best overall season, it's got to go in order and can't wait.Just hope they don't pussyfoot 6 plus months between releasing future seasons.

reviewText: I really love this show, it is one of my favorite Police Drama Shows.Fisrt telecasted on September 15th, 1977 until July 17th, 1983 for a total of 6 seasons which I hope will be released very shortly."CHiPs" was one of the best 30 TV shows by audience size reaching 18th on the Sept/1979 - April/1980 season with a percentage of 21.5% of all homes that had a TV were tuned to this show, and for your information the # 1 TV show was "60 Minutes" which had a percentage of 28.4%, only 6.9% difference.The cast were:*Officer Jon Baker(1977-1982).........Larry Wilcox*Officer Frank "Ponch" Poncherello....Erik Estrada*Sgt. Joe Getraer.....................Robert Pine*Officer Gene Fritz(1977-1981)........Lew Saunders*Officer Baricza(1977-1982)...........Brodie Greer*Officer Sindy Cahill(1978-1979)......Brianne Leary*Harlan(1978-1983)....................Lou Wagner*Officer Grossman.....................Paul Linke*Officer Bonnie Clark(1979-1982)......Randi Oakes*Officer Turner(1980-1982)............Michael Dorn*Officer Bobby Nelson(1982-1983)......Tom Reilly*Officer Kathy Linahan(1982-1983).....Tina Gayle*Cadet Bruce Nelson(1982-1983)........Bruce Penhall*Officer Webster(1982-1983)...........Clarence Gilyard,Jr.The First season consisted of 22 episodes and they are as follows:01-  Pilot  9/15/197702-  Undertow  9/22/197703-  Dog Gone  9/29/197704-  Moving Violation  10/13/197705-  Career Day  10/20/197706-  Baby Food  10/27/197707-  Taking Its Toll  11/3/197708-  Green Thumb Burglar  11/10/197709-  Hustle  11/24/197710-  Highway Robbery  12/1/197711-  Name Your Price  12/8/197712-  Aweigh We Go  12/22/197713-  One Two Many  1/5/197814-  Rustling  1/12/197815-  Surf's Up  1/19/197816-  Vintage '54  1/26/197817-  Hitch-Hiking Hitch  2/9/197818-  Cry Wolf  2/16/197819-  Crash Diet  2/23/197820-  Rainy Day  3/2/197821-  Crack-Up  3/9/197822-  Flashback!  4/1/1978I think this show deserve to be released season wise do to the fact that it is better than many shows being released.As the first season is being released soon I hope that all the following 5 seasons will be released shortly after. THANKS :)
summary: One of My Favorite Shows, 5 Stars for a very Exciting Show

reviewText: Wow, so I finally hear Chips was coming out on DVD and I thought to myself it's about time! I bought my season one and got it in the mail and let's just say VERY HAPPY!1. The Box set..  4 slim slipcases each include 2 disks.  The holders are very well made, they keep the discs in place and nice and secure, but at the same time they are very easy to pop out, unlike some other DVD sets I have purchased in the past.  I would have liked to maybe have had more liner notes about the series included, which their are very little included. All and all though I'm very pleased with the box set itself.2. Whats on the discs?  Well all time classic TV thats what. :)  I sat down and watched the first episode that started it all. Whats amazing to me is that after all these years since I last seen Chips on TV when I was much younger (I'm 35 now) many of the scenes in the first episode came back to me just like BAM!  The scene in which Ponches bike gets stuck in the glue lol I remember that like it was yesterday!  So fun to watch and I must say, they just don't make TV this good anymore in the 2007 times. Yes there are some good shows here and there, but you always have to worry about some foul language, or some offencive scene involved. Here with Chips you have just good clean fun comedy, with a positive messege for kids today and adults as well. If you want to watch some classic TV that you will enjoy years later, as well as TV that you can have your kids enjoy for years to come.  Get CHIPS!  I can't wait for the other seasons.Micah.
summary: Why can't TV shows STILL be this great!

reviewText: This has to be one of my favourite shows from when I was a kid, and when I heard about this coming to DVD I was excited. I bought this and The Fall Guy in the same week, and I have to say that I was more impressed with this set than The Fall Guy, although I love both shows.Warner Bros really does like to release things slowly, which frustrates me, but I am however glad that they decided to release this set. And what I find funny is that it wasn't even a Warner Bros show. If you watch the end credits of the show, the show was actually made by MGM. So I guess WB bought the rights for it, and released it.I do want to comment on the packaging for this set, though. I like the actual packaging, it's in the standard Cardboard box that holds 3 of the slim cases, which hold 2 discs each. However, my concern is with the artwork itself. I prefer the A-Team and Macgyver type packaging, where even though it contains the same artwork on the covers of each slim case, they have all the episode listings on the back of the case. The artwork for this set I find is horrible. For 1, the cover art is the most boring shot of Ponch and Jon I could think of, it doesn't show them in action or anything close to it. But onto the actual inner cases, it has no artwork on the actual cases themselves, it just shows little tiny pictures from various episodes, and contains the episode titles, and summaries on both sides of the case. I find it very confusing, and distracting. It looks very sloppy. Often times I go and look at it, and I can't tell which side of it is which. All it has for you to tell the difference is a little badge with the number of the disc up in the corner. I think all the episode titles, and all that should be listed on the back of the case, and have artwork on the front. It makes it less confusing that way. That's my only complaint about the artwork, or set in general.I know I'll die of old age waiting for some of my favourite shows to finally be released beyond their first seasons from Warner Bros (Everwood, Life Goes On, Night Court, etc) but with this set I was really impressed. I mean the picture and sound quality are a little bit questionable. I would say they really need to remix the sound because when I watch it, the music parts that play are super loud, but the dialogue is kind of low. I turn it up real loud on my surround system to hear the dialogue and then I blow people out of the room when a chase scene comes up because the music and sound effects are too loud.As for the picture quality though, you still see some crackle and dust in the picture, so I hope they go back and remaster it one day. But other than that this is a great set. This is one of those shows that doesn't get old. I watch these episodes over and over again, and don't get sick of them.I heard that Warner Bros is going to release season 2 next June, which will be around a year from the time that this was released, but I definitely recommend this set to anyone who is a fan of good storytelling, who likes a good laugh, and likes a lot of realism. This show has it all. Most episodes will keep you on the edge of your seat, from scenarios like trying to save a parachuter who is trapped on an overpass, to snakes in cars, to saving a mother and daughter who's car went over a bank, and is about to fall off a cliff.I give this show a 5 star rating because it has a lot of replay value, which most shows don't have. You can watch it over and over again. And is a good show for all ages, not just adults. I watched it when I was around 10, and my dad did when he was in his 30's, so that says a lot about the demographic that this show appeals to.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Really, when you think about it, this wasn't that great of a show. It's a tribute to bad disco music, razor-thin plots, and lack of realism. The crime of the day always ends 43 minutes into the episode. And Ponch's uniforms were always two sizes too small (even though John was the real hottie...)But just try, I say just try to stop watching once you start, especially if you were a kid or young teen when these were first on. For those of us in the Midwest, this show represented a whole lifestyle that we knew nothing about. Plus I'm sure we did subliminally absorb the safety lessons: like never leave your keys in the ignition, or don't light a flare around a gasoline truck.What made the show great in the beginning was the chemistry between 7-Mary-3 and 4. We all know that didn't last forever, but for this season it was right on. Plus the guest stars were a hoot (especially Rosey Greer credited as "Car Killer.") My favorites so far are "Baby Food" (contaminated baby food falls onto the freeway) "Surf's Up" (the boys request temporary reassignment and end up in Malibu) "Crack Up" (John gets hurt, and Ponch has to ride with Getraer) and Flashback (where we learn more about Ponch.)Yup, just try to resist this arresting collection...

reviewText: This is probably one of my all time favorites. Sure, it's not Shakespeare; but it's highly entertaining; none the less.This DVD set is nothing short of amazing; the picture is crystal clear; not digitally remastered; but it's in great shape. The audio is clear too. It looks like Ted Turner had a hand in this; I have to take my hat off to him and Warner; these are the network television releases; uncut and unedited; like they should be!There are six disks; easy to navigate through; unfortunately there are no English subtitles. But there is the all important; "Play All" feature.Some of the episodes have an opening introduction by Erik Estrada. It would have been nice to have Larry or Erik doing commentary; but I guess you can't have everything.All in all; this is a great set and judging by the way it's selling in the stores in my area; the other seasons should soon follow.
Title: N/A

reviewText: CHiPs: The Complete First SeasonI have to admit that I purchased the set for two reasons. One: This was one of my husband's favorite shows when it aired in the seventies. Two: My absolute favorite episode is, "Hustle," with a special appearance from Broderick Crawford. In a way, that episode brought everything full circle. How many youngsters sat in front of their TVs watching the old "Highway Patrol" series from the fifties and were influenced into becoming law officers? Upon meeting Mr. Crawford, Ponch talks about watching that old show "over and over," and now he is part of the California Highway Patrol. Great show! Plus, if you were a fan of the older show, you will be able to recognize some of the same location areas in the newer show, but as they are today.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This 1977-78 Season of this police drama is the season that started it all about 2 of California's Finest bachelors that rode together for 5 years who were virtually inseperable 24/7 even on their days off and were often surrounded by foxy women on and off-duty.California Highway Officer Frank "Ponch" Poncherello(Erik Estrada)was the often hot-headed, more trouble-prone traffic officer and his faithful partner was California Highway Patrol Officer Jon Baker(Larry Wilcox); an ex-Marine/Vietnam veteran whom was the more fortunate & more laid-back traffic officer and California Highway Patrol Sgt. Joe Getraer(Robert Pine)was their ornery superior officer from CHP Central Division in L.A. who frequently butted heads with Ponch & Jon along with the fact that CHiPs was the show that launched the acting career for both Erik Estrada & Larry Wilcox and made them stars along with the fact that Ponch & Jon were TV's sexiest cops back then on top of that.Additionally, CHiPs took place in the L.A. Area like most other police dramas did, except CHiPs was the first cop show about Highway Patrolman instead of another cop show about policemen since most other cop dramas were either about police officers or Deputy Sheriffs like ADAM-12, DRAGNET, TJ HOOKER, HUNTER, 240-ROBERT, SHERIFF LOBO, etc., for instance which was part of the reason why CHiPs was so unique back then in the late 70's and early 80's along with the fact that CHiPs was the most popular cop show on television with the most action at the time, especially when it made its debut on NBC back in the Fall of 1977 which also made me want to be a cop & made me want to move to Southern California, especially since its way prettier than the Imperial Valley is, which by the way is where I come from & where I was living at the time since I was an Imperial County resident from 1974-1995.Therefore CHiPs was not only the first cop show about California Highway Patrol Officers instead of another cop drama about police officers or sheriffs deputies, CHiPs was also the first cop drama about motorcycle officers as well since most other police dramas pertained to cops either patrolling in a cruiser or working investigations unlike CHiPs along with the fact that CHiPs was probably the first cop show about a Latino and an anglo partnering up together on a police force, especially way before NYPD BLUE came along in the 90's.The 1st Season of CHiPs also shows you how Ponch & Jon started out earlier in their law enforcement career with the California Highway Patrol and how they ended up meeting each other and how they became partners, like in the pilot episode and in the "Flashback" episode for instance when it tells us the untold story about Ponch & Jon all the way back to when they first became motor-cops and even before they went to CHP motor-school all the way back to the days when Jon was a solo patrolman in a cruiser like every chippie has to do for at least 2 years before they can ever become a motor officer or a CHP pilot.It was also interesting seeing guest stars like*Gerald McRaney in the "Aweigh We Go" episode before he became a star on his co-starring days as the short-tempered gonzo private investigator(Rick Simon)on SIMON & SIMON & before his co-starring days on MAJOR DAD, and TOUCHED BY AN ANGEL*Joe Penny before his co-starring days on RIPTIDE and JAKE & THE FATMAN*Mills Watson in the "Rustling" episode before his co-starring days as the doofus(Deputy Perkins) on SHERIFF LOBO*Ellen Travolta in the "Cry Wolf" episode before her co-starring days on CHARLES IN CHARGE*Deborah Pratt in the "Crash Diet" episode before her co-starring days as Archangel's assistant(Marilla) on AIRWOLF*G.W. Bailey in the "Rustling" episode before his co-starring days on POLICE ACADEMY*H.R. Puf'n'Stuf doing a cameo in the "Green Thumb Burglar" episode along with the voice of Lennie WeinribThis 1977-1978 Season also takes you back to Ponch & Jon's earlier days in their career when Ponch was living in his RV and had no car and when Jon had his little car instead of his bitchin blue 4X4 GMC Sierra Classic pick up, which goes to show you how Ponch and Jon worked their way up in life, especially by the 2nd Season along with the fact that CHiPs didn't even have a lady fellow officer in this season nor their own CHP mechanic in this season either along with the fact that CHiPs 1st Season was also the only season without a female co-star, without a female fellow officer,  and without a mechanic, since California Highway Patrol Officer Sindy Cahill(Brianne Leary) and CHP mechanic Harlan Arliss(Lou Wagner)didn't even join the cast and crew of CHiPs till the 2nd Season.The one thing that I can't help finding kind of odd about this police drama is Getraer along with quite a few other California Highway Patrolman would mention Sacramento and all the California Highway Patrols contacts up there since Sacramento is where the CHP headquarters and the CHP academy are both located at along with the fact that Sacramento is the capital of California on top of that, but I noticed that they still never ever showed one single episode of CHiPs in Sacramento or anywhere else in Northern California for that matter either and not even at the CHP academy either.Therefore, every single episode of CHiPs was only filmed here in Southern California and foremost in L.A. County even in the episodes where Jon & Ponch had a temporary transfer to patrol for another CHP division away from Central.For instance, in the "Aweigh We Go" episode; Getraer had Jon & Ponch temporarily transferred to the weigh station in the San Fernando Valley to patrol there to help local authorities crack down on semi-truck shipping thieves, which by the way even showed Ponch & Jon stopping at the "Six Flags Magic Mountain" amusement park in Valencia at one point.In the "Surfs Up" episode, Jon & Ponch request for an easier beat away from Central and Getraer surprisingly ends up temporarily transferring Ponch & Jon to patrol in beautiful Malibu where Jon & Ponch end up nabbing car strippers towards the end of the episode just before Jon & Ponch get transferred back to Central Division in Los Angeles.In the "Great 5K Star Race & Boulder Wrap Party", Ponch & Jon end up patrolling in Malibu to do traffic control on Pacific Coast Highway between Santa Monica & Malibu when a rock slide occurs causing a vicious mulitple traffic collison and when all the chippies end up at an event with numerous famous celebrities doing a cameo there like Milton Berle, George Peppard(The A-Team), Donna Miles, Gil Gerard(Buck Rogers), Susan Richardson(Eight Is Enough), Richard Kline(Three's Company), Todd Bridges(Different Strokes), Michael Warren(Hill Street Blues), Conrad Bain(Different Strokes), Chuck Woolery(Love Connection), Brian Kerwin(Sheriff Lobo), etc.Unfortunately, they never showed Ponch & Jon in Sacramento, but my hunch on why they never had any episodes in Sacramento is probably due to the fact that L.A. is the movie capital of the world along with the fact that Los Angeles is a lot more significant than Sacramento, plus has a lot of nice suburbs, unlike Sacramento along with the fact that LA is right next to Hollywood, not to mention that Hollywood is where they have the studios for the lookalike police station on CHiPs, which was the so-called CHP Central Division underneath the Santa Monica Freeway in L.A., plus Los Angeles is the biggest city with the largest population in the whole state of California on top of that, unlike Sacramento, which is why so many people believe that Los Angeles is the capital of California rather than Sacramento, despite the fact that L.A. was never the California state capital in the first place.Something else about this season that I couldn't help finding intriguing was I noticed that Michael Dorn which played Ponch & Jon's fellow Officer(Jeb Turner)in the 3rd, 4th, and 5th Seasons of this show which by the way replaced Officer Gene Fritz(Lew Saunders)as the new 7-David in the 1979-80 Season, was used as an extra in a CHP uniform in a lot of episodes in this 1977-1978 Season, especially at the police station like in the episodes "Undertow", "Career Day", "Hustle", "One Two Many", "Rustling", etc.Something I couldn't help finding odd about this cop drama was even though Ponch & Jon along with the rest of their fellow officers always wore their CHP Summer uniform in the first half of each season & would wear their CHP Winter uniform in the second half of each season, except none of them ever wore a tie with their Winter uniform unlike most other California Highway Patrolmen which sometimes made their long-sleeved uniforms look less professional since the blue tie on the CHP's Winter uniform stands out a lot more & looks a lot more professional just like the tie does on most other law enforcement agencies Winter uniforms like LAPD and the L.A. County Sheriffs Office does too.So now, I can hardly wait for the 2nd Season and beyond to come out on DVD, since the Second Season is even better and is obviously a definite serious upgrade to the First Season of CHiPs.
summary: The Season That Started It All
Title: N/A

reviewText: It has been a long time, ten years for me, since I saw this show the last time. Therefore I was surprised that the show played in the late 70s. I always assumed that it played in the 80s. The introduction to selected episodes by Erik Estrada are great but I would have liked some commentaries by the cast on select episodes. I am really glad however that they got Erik Estrada to sit down and talk about the show. There are so many older and even a few more recent shows like Charmed being released on DVD without any extras. The picture quality for a show this old is ok in my opinion.This show is a must buy.

reviewText: What can you say about Chips? Eric Estrada and Larry Wilcox are at their best. I especially love the 70's muscle driving in the background.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Either a show has it or it hasn't. Some shows like this have IT and then some. The characters are just so natural and do their jobs so routinely you HAVE to believe it and that makes all the difference. Sadly you can't even say that it is "expertly cast" because this type of light-n-ing either hits or it doesn't; rarely is it "kind of".I have to add the "also starring Robert Pine" part of the show is bigger than the lazy "also" would indicate. Sgt. Joe Getraer is the lug (nothing personal:) that keeps the tire on the bike. Ponchs' mishaps would be GREATLY diminished without his perfect annoyance.But I suppose the heart of CHiPs is.. our guys:) Larry Wilcox and Erik Estrada are not only fun to watch but have fairly superb dramatic abilities which not every actor around has; usually it's either - or. Watching this set you just get the feeling they are average guys doing an anything but average job and what's truly fun; it's seems you are really along for the ride! Adam 12 "sort of" had that ride along quality but the show IMO is so stiff you never truly got that sense.The packaging; as beautiful as it is could have used some more representation from the rest of the precinct. Why no pics of Bear or Joe Getraer upon opening discs 3 and 4? Or at least DIFFERENT pics of Ponch and Jon? Would it have been that tough? On a technical level, the video quality tends to vary, but hey, it's the 70's, whatcha gonna do?So, why not 5 stars? Umm... the guest stars, or the people Ponch and Jon interact with (read: the public) are often laughable. Not funny "haha" but funny as in ...WOW what a TERRIBLE actor. There are a couple of bright spots; I like Jons ex-teammate from High School but overall the acting and casting of everyone except the core cast is fair to poor. Hopefully, Season 2 rectifies some of this but even still I will buy that on Day One.I wish I could end this review in the fun filled "way" each episode ends but let's just say that's another highlight that must be seen to be appreciated... like gas at 60 cents a gallon or shots of Alpha Beta Markets. Remember those?
Title: N/A
